data.title: Create more than one new file at a time
data.body: Currently you can only create one new, unsaved file at at time in Atom. We should allow for any number of new files to be created. As it stands now, hitting Cmd+N will just focus you on the existing new file's tab.

data.title: specs cannot be run from release build
data.body:
I was trying to be good and help out with some Atom plugin development, but I couldn't run the specs. The confusing thing is that it seemed like I could, but nothing happened.

Then @kevinsawicki pointed out I have to build Atom to run specs.

data.title: Better line movement when soft wrap is enabled.
data.body:
I'm not sure if all of these are needed, but here is a list of line commands that I'd like to make work better when a buffer is soft wrapped.
- [x] `editor:move-to-end-of-line`
- [x] `editor:move-to-beginning-of-line`
- [x] `editor:move-to-first-character-of-line` 
- [x] `editor:cut-to-end-of-line`
- [x] `editor:newline-below`
- [x] `editor:newline-above`
- [ ] `editor:delete-line` (ignoring because sublime and textmate do)
- [ ] `editor:move-line-up`  (ignoring because sublime and textmate do)
- [ ] `editor:move-line-down`  (ignoring because sublime and textmate do)
- [ ] `editor:duplicate-line`  (ignoring because sublime and textmate do)

Fixing #673 so @briandoll can make this money.

data.title: Autocomplete CSS'ings
data.body:
One of the last things I'm missing in Atom (coming from Sublime) is autocomplete css elements. Elements drop down and tab complete. Makes it especially nice if you've forgotten or don't use the elements often. 

![animated-2013-08-06_12h-42m-24s-1](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/51578/918585/578c44c4-feb7-11e2-9f69-4a6718c50952.gif)

I'm happy to help add this plugin anyway I can but would be an amazing feature to have as we launch to the world.

data.title: Tab indentation incorrectly assumes snippets
data.body:
![tab_snippet_error](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/64050/912652/b72dc022-fe05-11e2-9361-b2aa2aa75f37.gif)

The error says:

```
Uncaught TypeError: Cannot call method 'match' of undefined 
```

Lines of code:

``` ruby
        begin
          target_filepath = File.realpath(includes_filepath, source_directory)

        if File.file?(target_filepath)
          target_contents = File.read(target_filepath)

          while INCLUDES.match target_contents do
            target_contents = replace(target_contents)
          end
        end
```

data.title: Trailing blank line whitespace truncated
data.body:
It looks like I have a file that:
- Visually has a blank line after content inside of Atom
- Doesn't _actually_ retain that blank line when I save (checked in both vim and github.com)

I noticed this from editing a file that had a blank line and then editing that file. I didn't change it itself- I was working elsewhere in the file. I tried adding `whitespace.ensureSingleTrailingNewline` to my config but that didn't seem to do anything. It seems like Atom is stripping it on save (but still visually looking correct in-editor).

data.title: Incorrect text selection when using soft wrap and keyboard navigation
data.body:
I write me some prose and shit. I soft wrap. Don't hate. I got some long multi-line shit going on, let's say 4 lines. My cursor is after the last character on the 4th soft-wrapped line. I realize I don't know what the fuck I'm saying on this line, so imma delete line 4 and start again.

Now, if I were laying with another editor, or a textarea for that matter, you know what would happen? That 4th line would be all highlighted and shit, I'd delete it, and I'd start again. Ain't nobody get hurt.

Say I try that in Atom. Say I'm tired. I use some fancy keyboardin' and I command shift kickflip left arrow. Know what happens? Whole gosh darn 4 lines be highlighted. And you know I gots the trigger finger, so that delete be hit right quick and next thing you know the whole gosh darn paragraph just go poof. Just like that.

I repeat those steps about 5 times before I says to myself.. self... that is a git darn bug if ever I did see one. And here we are.

mmhhhmmmm

data.title: Panes within tabs?
data.body:
I have a Vim workflow that I am having trouble recreating in Atom. Most of my tabs consist of a split, for a file and its tests:

![srt_imports rb _github_talks_app_concerns_talk - vim](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/12676/896074/195b3ef8-fad9-11e2-8bcb-80e85ab7ab8e.png)

Thus I can `{` and `}` my way through tabs and `[` and `]` my way through splits within them, and all was right with the world. My splits are about keeping related files together, not separate panes or editors.

The modeling of `Pane` and `EditSession` doesn't really allow this right now. It's fairly easy to see a number of ways to do it, but I was stymied when I started to edit core stuff by things marked as internal. @kevinsawicki said to ignore that, so I'm going to slowly work on something that works for me. But he also said to make an issue, so here it is. I'm hoping that one of you core guys sees a super easy way to do it :)

data.title: Move to atom/atom
data.body: I know it's a big deal, but it seems like the right thing to do. What do you think?

data.title: Keymap Improvements
data.body:
So @nathansobo and I were talking about how to handle complex keybindings for first class vim support during summit.

I've run into several issues while thinking about it. The first is issue are vim's `dd` and `d{motion}` (like `diw`) commands which ideally would have separate lines in the keymap file so users could remap them as they wish. Something along the lines of this:

```
".vim-mode":
  "d d": "vim-mode:delete-line"
  "d" : "vim-mode:delete"
  "i w" : "vim-mode:motion-inner-word"
```

Unfortunately the keymap currently fires the first binding that matches. Therefore if a user types 'd d' it will trigger `vim-mode:delete` twice instead of triggering `vim-mode:delete-line` once.

Another issue I've found that I wish we had a way to do some basic globbing:

```
".vim-mode":
  '" [a-zA-Z]': "vim-mode:register-prefix"
```

This syntax would allow me to restrict the possible keys entered without exhaustively listing them. If it's easier maybe we could just accept regexps here rather than trying to create a subset?

Note: This is also required for `f` and `t` motions.

I'd like to hear what others think about these proposals.

data.title: Editor#selectToBeginningOfNextWord with leading spaces.
data.body:
Given a buffer that contains this "ab  cde1+- \n" and a cursor at [0,2], if you call editor.selectToBeginningOfNextWord, it will select "  cde1". 

I believe it should select "  " based on it's naming, thoughts?

data.title: Accidentaled web inspector
Old Session URLs
Make soft wrap an editor preference
data.body: Currently I have to turn on soft wrapping for every file as I don't believe it's an editor-wide preference. Would love to see this added.

data.title: Show volume level on participant view
data.body: WebAudio and WebRTC don't currently work together. When [this patch](https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=121673&q=webaudio%20webrtc&colspec=ID%20Pri%20M%20Iteration%20ReleaseBlock%20Cr%20Status%20Owner%20Summary%20OS%20Modified) lands we should fix this.

data.title: Update Octicons
data.body:
Atom's using an outdated version of Octicons; this is probably going to make upgrading in the future much harder.

For the most part this is a simple drop-in but there are some styles, like `ios` or `download-android`, that are referenced in Atom's LESS files, but were removed from Octicons. Interestingly, though, these OS-specific styles aren't even being used in Atom.

data.title: Stop including bundled packages directly in the source tree
data.body:
Currently, we store the packages that we bundle with the Atom binary directly in `src/packages`. It would be great to pull these out in separate repositories and reference them from Atom's `package.json` instead.

**But** in order to do this we need efficient tooling for running tests on all bundled packages when we change Atom's core APIs and editing them in situ.

We're thinking of some apm commands like the following:
- `apm update` This prunes anything in `node_modules` that isn't mentioned in `package.json` and upgrades/installs anything that is mentioned.
- `apm develop [package-name]` This clones, checks out the correct revision, and symlinks all Atom packages in the `package.json` or the named package.
- `apm outdated` This looks for any new published versions of packages mentioned in `package.json` and lists them. It might also be nice to have a command (maybe a flag to `apm update`) that automatically writes to `package.json` and pulls the updated packages into `node_modules`.

data.title: newlines follow last line's indent
data.body:
When you hit enter/newline, the default indent choice, when no lang specific indent was the last non blank row's indent. For me, this would often indent more than I wanted (say, I'm creating a new function after some other function).

So this pull changes the default indent to be the last line's indent instead. That way I can tab back a few, and hit enter as many times as I want without it messing up my tabbing.

data.body: Will fix #634

data.title: Make autoflow indent and comment aware
data.body:
- Update autoflow to have same structure as other plugins (in lib dir)
- Add key shortcut
- Dont attach with root view so it now only shows in meta+p panel when editor is focused.
- Make it indent aware
- Make it handle comment chars at the beginning 
  - it is dumb -- doesnt actually use info from lang mode...yet
  - maybe could do checking to see if it is inside of a comment block and handle accordingly?
  - or could just use the actual single comment char.

data.title: Move cursor to end of selection
data.body:
In other editors, when you have something selected, and you move the cursor left or right, the cursor goes to the respective end of the selection. In atom, it would ignore the selection and just move the cursor irrespective of selection state. 

On cursor up and down, the cursor should go to the line above the selection or to the line below the selection, respectively. This is the way other editors work, including web textareas.

The crappiest thing I added was an options hash to the `move*` functions. There is now a `moveToEndOfSelection` option. The `moveToEndOfSelection` is properly set by the `EditSession`.

data.title: Cmd+N should be new file
data.body: Instead of Cmd+N opening a new window, I propose Cmd+N be the new file shortcut while Cmd+Shift+N be the new window shortcut. Seems to fit in with existing shortcut patterns elsewhere and in app.

data.title: Add indexForBufferPosition method to EditSession
data.body:
I'm working on creating an Emmet plugin for Atom.

Most of what needs to be done is overriding Emmet functionality to work with Atom's API. Most of the interactions with Emmet expect character index positions in a document. Basically, this necessitates translating `[row, column]` positions into the index position.

I'd like to add the `indexForBufferPosition and`bufferPositionForIndex` to translate between the two positions. You can see it [used here](https://github.com/atom/emmet/blob/1e274e258956ed67a14f059e1186405ef78194ab/lib/editor-proxy.coffee#L107-L116).

Ideally I would prefer this to go right into `Point`, but the whole point is that it depends on `@buffer` to know how to calculate previous line lengths.

data.title: Atom doesn't warn when keybindings conflict
data.body:
I thought the editor used to do this check?

I created a package that bound `meta-e` to `.editor`. My package wouldn't work, until I eventually found out that `meta-e` was already bound from _command-panel_.
